text:
I'm a bit afraid of this change as we don't really have control on the input. For example, with imgs="test.nii", this will not work as strings are iterable. And I'm sure that we can find other weird cases. This is why NiftiStuffMasker are declined in Single and Multi flavors: accepting any dimensionality of data was too messy.

Plus documentation is not updated.

I would go for feeding ['test.nii'] to canica for single subject and postponing this behavior for later when we will have time to think it through. Apart from that, +1 for merge.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/decomposition/base.py')

text:
To reply to @AlexandreAbraham 's comment: in a sense, yes, it's a bit of a quick hack. However, it's a very light modification and it makes the code work like the user expects it: asking the user to do fit(['fmri.nii']) is not good. In addition, the current error

In the long run, maybe we should think about this in the same time as when we do the globbiing.

I have made sure that strings are well handle (as per @AlexandreAbraham 's remark).

text:
I agree that the strategy is hard to describe. Instead of describing it, I think that you should at least state what is the purpose of the "auto" keyword:

The default strategy, corresponding to "auto", computes a threshold that seeks to minimize (yet not eliminate completely) the overlap between maps for a better display.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py')

text:
It is a bit convoluted. I would simplify:

If None, no threshold is applied.

Even better:

If None, a very small threshold is applied to remove numerical noise from the maps background.
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py')

text:
> to remove numerical noise from the maps background

A bit technical for user. I would keep this: "If None, no threshold is applied."
title: (None, '', u'nilearn/plotting/img_plotting.py')

text: I would say "The threshold can also be expressed as a percentile over the values of the whole atlas. In that case, the value must be specified in a string ending with a percent sign, e.g., "25.3%"."

text:
You are right, we should accept colormap names. In the meantime, you can use this workaround:

``` python
from matplotlib.cm import get_cmap

display = plotting.plot_connectome(delta_edge, 
                         networks_coords[3:], 
                         display_mode = 'y',
                         node_color= networks_cols[3:],  
                         colorbar=True,                         
                         edge_cmap = get_cmap('Blues'),
                         edge_vmin = 0,
                         edge_vmax = 0.075,
                         annotate = False,
                         );       
```
